title: 114_s3160
content: The Act may be cited as the "Securing our Secrets Act" or the "SOS Act". Definitions are provided in the Act. The "Securing our Secrets Act" defines key terms such as "appropriate congressional committees," "Department," "infraction," "Inspector General," and "intelligence community." The term "community" is defined as per the National Security Act of 1947. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of State. SEC. 3. USE OF NONGOVERNMENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS. Employees of the Department must use only Department-owned electronic communication systems for work-related communications. The Secretary must certify annually that all employees have access to these systems. If certification cannot be made, a report must be provided to the appropriate congressional committees. If the Secretary cannot certify that all Department employees have access to work-related electronic communication systems, a report must be submitted to Congress detailing the number of employees without access, reasons for the lack of access, steps taken to provide access, and measures to ensure proper handling of classified information. The Secretary may waive these requirements for up to 10 employees on a case-by-case basis. The Secretary can waive requirements for up to 10 employees if it is in the national security interest of the United States and if all work-related communications are properly archived. The Secretary can waive requirements for up to 10 employees if it is in the national security interest of the United States. The waivers are valid for up to 180 days and can be reissued. The Secretary may issue multiple waivers if consistent with certification and justification. The Inspector General will develop an oversight plan to ensure compliance within 90 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. REPORT ON SECURITY REVIEWS AND VIOLATIONS. The Secretary must submit an annual report detailing security violations, including unauthorized transfer of classified information, with information on responsible employees, violation dates, descriptions, compromised information, violated laws, and response actions taken by the Department officials. The annual report must include details of security violations, actions taken by officials in response to the violations, and privacy protections under the Privacy Act of 1974. SEC. 5. CLASSIFIED INFORMATION SPILLAGE. SEC. 5 requires the Secretary to appoint officials for training in detecting classified information spillage and conducting randomized sampling of emails. The Inspector General will audit this work and report findings to congressional committees. The Secretary must certify that all Department personnel with security clearances have completed emergency refresher training on handling classified information, including rules for electronic transmission and derivative classification. The curr_chunk discusses the handling and transmission of foreign government information, processing requests under the Freedom of Information Act, challenges to classification status, and protecting classified information that has been disclosed without authorization. The curr_chunk outlines the requirements of Executive Order 13526 (2009) regarding the declassification of classified information, the Secretary's responsibilities in implementing classified information programs, and the designation of a senior agency official to oversee the program. The curr_chunk outlines the requirements for personnel retraining on classified information, including penalties for violations and a signed certification by employees. The Secretary must prioritize emergency refresher training for employees with security clearances in a specific order. The Secretary can delay training for up to 30 days for critical foreign policy reasons with notification to congressional committees. The section defines applicable rules and procedures. The section defines "applicable rules and procedures" as any relevant federal statutes, Executive Orders, executive orders on classified information, the Foreign Affairs Manual, and Departmental guidance or regulations. SEC. 7. ENDURING TRAINING PROGRAM TO PREVENT MISHANDLING OF INTELLIGENCE INFORMATION. The Secretary must establish a training program for Department employees on preventing the transfer of classified information to unauthorized systems. SEC. 8. PLAN FOR REFORMING RESPONSE TO REQUESTS FOR INFORMATION AND INFORMATION ARCHIVING. The Secretary must submit a plan within 90 days for completing reforms related to training Department employees in identifying classified information and ensuring proper classification procedures. The intelligence community officials have the opportunity to determine the classification status of information. A training program will be developed for Department officials on archiving electronic communications. Employees must annually certify that they have archived all documents in accordance with relevant laws and regulations. The Inspector General will report to congressional committees on the Secretary's implementation of the plan for appropriate archiving and securing of information by the Department within one year of the Act's enactment.
